awd_titl_txt: Advancing Mechatronics Education to Include Industry 4.0 Concepts and Skills
awd_abstract_narration:
The field of advanced manufacturing is being transformed by the integration of automation with digital data exchange.  This integration of physical and digital systems is often called, Industry 4.0.  Examples of Industry 4.0 technologies include Artificial Intelligence, the Internet of Things, and Cloud Computing. This project is designed to help meet the rising need for highly skilled workers who are ready for employment in Mechatronics and Industry 4.0. The College’s South Georgia service area is home to more than 150 manufacturing companies.  Current industry partners include Polar Beverages, Kelly Manufacturing Company, Campbell Scientific, NextEra Energy, Dillard’s Distribution, Letica Corporation, BASF, and Innotek. To operate and maintain modern manufacturing facilities, these companies need technicians who have Industry 4.0 skills. Coupled with this growing demand for Industry 4.0-competent technicians, there is a shortage of faculty who can teach Industry 4.0 concepts and skills. To meet the dual need for educators and workers, this project plans to: 1) build on an existing mechatronics program to develop a new Mechatronics – Industry 4.0 degree that can produce workforce-ready technicians; 2) develop educational pathways from local high school mechatronics programs into the new Mechatronics – Industry 4.0 program; 3) support the teaching and learning of workplace Industry 4.0 competencies; and 4) increase program enrollment, especially of underrepresented student populations including female and Latinx students. A comprehensive evaluation will determine the impact of the project as well as make recommendations for modifications.

This project intends to develop a pipeline of students from a high-school advanced manufacturing program into a college-level Mechatronics program that includes Industry 4.0 training. Using industry experts as co-teachers, professional development activities will provide college faculty with the necessary training and certifications needed to provide high quality education in Industry 4.0 concepts and skills. The project will develop blended-learning resources (i.e. in person and online) and generate insights into how a blended environment affects student learning. Anticipated outcomes of the project are an advanced mechatronics degree with an Industry 4.0 focus and articulated pathways in automated manufacturing from high schools to community and technical colleges. Anticipated benefits to industry partners include: 1) a steady stream of highly skilled, work-ready advanced manufacturing technicians; 2) a curriculum more reflective of industry needs; and 3) an opportunity to shape the educational future of students interested in advanced manufacturing as a career path. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Advancing Mechatronics Education to Include Industry 4.0 (Ind 4.0) grant plans to accomplish four distinct goals. The first is to build on existing mechatronics programs to develop a new program that focuses on the implementation of Industry 4.0 technology. The second goal focuses on the development of educational pathways, from high school to the post-secondary Industry 4.0 program. The third goal is to provide support to teaching and learning workplaces by furthering professional development. The fourth is to grow enrollment through outreach to underrepresented student populations including female and Hispanic students.

Year one of the Ind 4.0 grant introduced several hurdles. Like many other grants, the Ind4.0 grant was stagnated by the COVID-19 pandemic. Our year-one goals would be uprooted and shifted to accommodate the myriad of changes that COVID-19 introduced to our workflow. All travel arrangements were canceled, including training for professional development and research. In response to the inability to travel, we rescheduled our professional development to training that could be provided virtually. Select faculty, including the PI and Co-PI would attend virtual training provided by ABB Robotics and NC3.   

The travel restrictions also shifted the in-person meetings scheduled for the business and industry leadership team (BILT). The BILT would meet virtually every month to discuss the direction of progress. The grant leadership team then shaped standards for program implantation with guidance from the BILT.

The second major hurdle introduced was Georgia House Bill 444. GA HB 444 aims to eliminate cost by limiting the number of credit hours dually enrolled high school students can take. In reaction to HB 444, high schools in our area quickly pulled support for elective programs that were not essential for high school graduates, such as the mechatronics program. This closed our pathway in secondary institutions during year one.  

In year two of the Ind4.0 grant, the leadership team finalized standards and documentation for state accreditation. The standards cover all course competencies for a two-year associate degree in Industry 4.0 technology. After obtaining state accreditation from the Technical College System of Georgia, the program was submitted for regional accreditation with The Southern Association of College and Schools Commission on Colleges (SACSCOC).  

To build relations with secondary schools, a recruiter was hired in year two of the grant. The recruiter was tasked with creating an outreach program. This outreach program was also tasked with engaging with specific demographics that align with goal four. The recruiter was able to establish strong connections with high schools and take the first steps to reestablish relationships.  

To further support teaching and learning in the workplace, the grant leadership team provided staff development opportunities. Wiregrass and TCSG faculty responsible for electronics, mechatronics, and industrial systems education were given training opportunities throughout years two and three of the grant. Alongside technical skills training, the leadership team also provided an interactive training session to promote program development. This training provided an overview of new state Industry 4.0 standards and the technology reflected in each standard. An overview of the new program was also presented to the Technical College System of Georgia vice presidents of academic affairs, vice presidents of economic development, and technical instructors throughout the state.

In year three of the Ind 4.0 grant, Wiregrass Georgia Technical College introduced the SACSCOC-accredited Industry 4.0 Technology Associates Degree. This new program is supported by the college’s online learning platform called Blackboard. This program will also be supported with new equipment that highlights cyber-physical education. The new program was advertised across different channels within the college’s eleven-county service area using radio and podcast interviews. WGTC opened enrollment for the program in Spring 2023.

NCE 2024

The NCE has allowed additional time to allocate funds that furthered the intended goals of the grant. The remaining funds were used to purchase skills automation training units. Each unit is multifunctional and can address various competencies within the newly developed Industry 4.0 program as well as the existing Mechatronics program. These trainers will allow classroom education to align with real-world applications that involve cyber-physical equipment.
